Problem:
Consider the space of complex functions \\(z(t)\\) governed by the differential equation \\(\\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z\\), where \\(\\omega\\) is a real constant. Suppose we apply an integral transformation represented by \\(\\hat{z}(s) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st}z(t) dt\\), where \\(s\\) is a complex constant.

If the transformation \\(\\hat{z}(s)\\) is applied to a function \\(z_0(t)\\) at time \\(t = 0\\), and then allowed to evolve under \\(\\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z\\) without further intervention, does \\(\\hat{z}(s)\\) at any future time \\(T\\) represent the same transform as if \\(z_0(t)\\) was directly evolved to \\(T\\) under \\(\\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z\\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\(\\hat{z}(s)\\) is a linear and time-invariant operator due to its integral nature over exponentials. Hence, the initial transformation and subsequent evolution governed by \\(\\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z\\) will yield the same result irrespective of the initial condition or the progression of time.
